none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, September 9, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, September 9, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 21 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Personal letter from T. M. Scott to Professor Louis L. McInnis dated September 9, 1885, inquiring about McInnis's family and work at College Station. The letter references an ongoing administrative matter involving General H., Colonel Pfeuffer, and other officials regarding a house building application and authority questions, and requests information about student enrollment and session prospects for the institution.

body.value:
Melissa, Texas.
Sept. 9th 1885.

Prof.
L. L. McInnis,
Colleg Station.

My dear McInnis,

Why have you never answerd
the letter I wrote you from Wax-
ahatchie, I wrote you [illegible] how enthu
siastically my repor[illegible]res
tion went through
everything I asked
expected you would [illegible]
rejoice with me. [illegible] assign
I suppose you are regular
down to work now, Your wife
and little one with you, and
you supremely happy, my
kind regards to the mother and
a kiss for the baby.

A portion of a letter from

**Analysis and Transcription of a Damaged Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's dive into this. The task is clear: transcribe this handwritten letter, dealing with damage and all. First, I need to understand the source. It’s a letter on lined paper, clearly handwritten with cursive, showing some wear and tear, especially a nasty tear down the right side. The date and location are at the top, Melissa, Texas, dated September 9th, 1885. The recipient? Prof. L.L. McInnis, at College Station.

Now for the content. The writer seems to be asking why McInnis hasn’t responded to a previous letter sent from Waxahatchie. There’s a mention of some enthusiastic "report" or "reputation" making its way through.  The writer also references asking for something and anticipates rejoicing. Then, the letter shifts to McInnis’s life – work, his wife, and a baby, ending with just a fragment about another letter.

Okay, time to transcribe, line by line.

*   **Header:** Starting with the date and location: "Melissa, Texas." and "Sept. 9th 1885." The "th" in "9th" looks superscript and there might be underlining or double underline, so I'll render that with an html tag.
*   **Addressee:** "Prof." is straightforward. Then comes the name "L. L. McInnis," or "S. S."? Looking carefully, the initials look like cursive capital "L" and the loops confirm this. Historical context of L. L. McInnis fits the bill. "Colleg Station." or maybe just "Colleg". Let's stick with what's visible. I'll stick to `Colleg`.
*   **Salutation:** "My dear McInnis,"
*   **Body:** Now, here's where it gets interesting. I need to make sure I get the spellings.  I will write "Why have you never answerd" (or is it answered? but it looks like answerd - a flat 'e'). "the letter I wrote you from Wax-" ... Then, a tear. The original text might read "...ahatchie, I wrote you [tear] how enthu" or is that "tell you". The next word, fortunately, "siastically," is clear, so it’s likely "enthusiastically".  Following the tear, there's `repor[illegible]res` the word has a tear, but it looks like "repor." and then an isolated `res`. The next line is `tion`. It could be "report" or "reputation", but the context needs `tion`, so "reputation" it is. I will be careful to render what I can see. "everything I asked" is clear. Following there is a tear, so the line is `expected you would [tear]`. Then `rejoice with me. [tear] assign` and after a tear, it looks like `assign`. Next line `I suppose you are regular` or `regularly`. It has a vertical line at the edge, and the previous one makes sense. The letter continues, with "down to work now, Your wife and little one with you, and you supremely happy, my kind regards to the mother and a kiss for the baby."
*   **Footer:** There's a fragment at the bottom, “A portion of a letter from.”

The main challenge is that tear that disrupts the flow. There seem to be some fragments of letters, that don't make sense as part of the line. So it reads: `...how enthu` ,  and the isolated word  `res` . And also `assign` that might have been part of the word before. Now the final transcription.

```

Sept. 9th 1885.

L. L. McInnis,
Colleg Station.
My dear McInnis,
Why have you never answerd
the letter I wrote you from Wax-
ahatchie, I wrote you [illegible] how enthu
siastically my repor[illegible]res
tion went through
everything I asked
expected you would [illegible]
rejoice with me. [illegible] assign
I suppose you are regular
down to work now, Your wife
and little one with you, and
you supremely happy, my
kind regards to the mother and
a kiss for the baby.
A portion of a letter from
```

Gen'l H. to Col Pfeuffer has just passed through my hand for endorsement, with action by Willy & Garrison, and after mine then to Cavitt and back to Gen'l H. The matter refered to lecertis' house and application to build a house and what autherity the Gen'l Profess[illegible] to houses, manifested in the [illegible] cation is not stopp[illegible] it will eventuate in a "[illegible]st up." I wish you could [illegible]tly get and read the whole affair. you will see Willy & Garrison did not "catch on"; I would like to see Cavitt's endorsement How many students have you in attendance and what is the prospects for the session? I hope we will have a good school th[illegible]

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's get down to brass tacks. I've got a handwritten letter here, and the user wants a transcription. The image itself is a bit rough—lined paper, a cursive scrawl, some ink smudges, and a good chunk missing from the right side. The handwriting's generally legible, but there are a few quirky letter formations that require close scrutiny, like that "G" in "Gen'l," or the way certain letters slant.

First, line by line: "Gen'l H. to Col Pfeuffer has" – pretty straightforward, the "Gen'l" is General, and "Col" is Colonel. The "H." is likely a name.

"just passed through my hand" – clear enough.

"for endorsement, with action" – still clear.

"by Willy & Garrison, and after" – Now, here's where it gets interesting. I initially had some difficulty discerning the first name. Is it "Willy" or "Dilly"? After careful consideration of the letter formation, comparing to other capital Ws, comparing also to historical context, and examining the second instance which has an insertion with a caret. I will use "Willy." I'm also fairly sure I have context, given the names. "Willy & Garrison" could be a company or pair of officials.

"mine then to Cavitt and back" – "Cavitt" is likely W.R. Cavitt, and I'm starting to get a sense of the historical context: Texas A&M. I suspect "Gen'l H" is also a historical figure, I will research it.

"to Gen'l H. The matter refered to" – "refered" is, of course, a misspelling.

"lecertis' house and application" – This is where it gets tricky, the word here. The main problem is the first word. It has a tall loop at the beginning and a trailing 's'. After much consideration. I will transcribe it as "lecertis'". However, it could be "Secretary's". It *looks* like "lecertis", but the historical context may imply this could be a proper name.

"to build a house and what" – straightforward, "build a house".

"autherity the Gen'l" – "autherity" is misspelled.

"Profess[illegible] to houses," – the torn area, and there is something here. "Profess" is underlined, and that's key. It could be "Proposes." This might be a name. I will transcribe it as "[illegible]" with a note.

"manifested in the [illegible]" – tear, lost text.

"cation is not stopp[illegible] it will" – more lost text in a torn region.

"eventuate in a "[illegible]st up." – I bet this says "bust up." There is a quote at the end.

"I wish you could [illegible]tly" – "quietly" seems like the most likely word.

"get and read the whole affair." – clear.

"you will see Willy & Garrison" – insertion via caret.

"did not "catch on"; I would" – a semicolon/comma.

"like to see Cavitt's endorsement" – clear, possesive.

"How many students" – clear.

"have you in attendance" – clear.

"and what is the prospects" – grammar issue: "is" should be "are". I will transcribe as is.

"for the session? I hope we" – question mark.

"will have a good school" – clear.

"th[illegible]" – the end of the letter.

So, in the end, it is:

Gen'l H. to Col Pfeuffer has
just passed through my hand
for endorsement, with action
by Willy & Garrison, and after
mine then to Cavitt and back
to Gen'l H. The matter refered to
lecertis' house and application
to build a house and what
autherity the Gen'l
Profess[illegible] to houses,
manifested in the [illegible]
cation is not stopp[illegible] it will
eventuate in a "[illegible]st up."
I wish you could [illegible]tly
get and read the whole affair.
you will see Willy & Garrison
did not "catch on"; I would
like to see Cavitt's endorsement
How many students
have you in attendance
and what is the prospects
for the session? I hope we
will have a good school
th[illegible]

this time,
Write me a long letter
and tell me all I want
to know.
That the good Lord may
now and ever, have you
and yours in his kind care
is the daily wish of your
friend
T M [?]

[T. M. Scott]

**Final Thoughts on Transcription** Alright, let's get this done. The task is straightforward: transcribe the provided image, a fragment of an old handwritten letter, into HTML, paying close attention to formatting and nuances. My primary goal is accuracy, while faithfully reflecting the original layout and the nature of the handwriting. First, I analyzed the image. It's clearly a letter fragment, the paper aged and torn. The handwriting is cursive, probably late 19th or early 20th century. I can see ten lines of text, though the top and signature are partially obscured. I want to render that accurately. My strategy involves preserving line breaks with `
`, wrapping the transcription in `

` tags for semantic paragraphs, and handling the damaged areas. The biggest challenge is the torn signature. I've examined it closely; It looks like "T M" is the visible portion, and the pencil annotation "\[T. M. Scott]" will need to be included. I'll represent the damaged part of the signature with `[?]`. I'll use simple HTML, no fancy Markdown, following the specified format. The pencil annotation looks like a later addition, separate from the original text. I've crafted and refined the HTML, paying close attention to details. It's got the top line cut off as "this time,", the line breaks, the text, and the signature represented as "T M [?]". The annotation is in its own paragraph. I've re-checked the text for accuracy and consistency, like making sure the 't' in the first line is transcribed as seen. I've had several checks of the image, and a final check of the text against the formatting requirements. I'm ready to produce the result in its HTML form.
